Thanks for your review @rangadi. 

The only purpose of this backlog size counting is to enable autoscaling. Kinesis API does not provide any information about the remaining events in the stream so I had to use the CloudWatch service in order to get that info. I've also introduced the allowedRecordLateness parameter in order to limit the autoscaling when events are not that much late. It helped in our case when we observed workers count fluctuations due to temporary events bursts.
@kennknowles  Thanks for your review. I have sent out the email of ICLA today. Any response on this, I will let you know.
Replied inline to comments in the code. I do see why you have 'threshold', my comment was mainly about the 'lateness' in the name.
R: @vikkyrk

@jkff Thank you for your suggestions! They improved and simplified my implementation a lot.

Writing the javadoc comments, I found two design questions still exist:

1. Would it be more beneficial to work with `KV<ResourceID, byte[]>` than `KV<String, byte[]>`? The current approach gives users only the filename and disregards full paths or intermediate directories (between `/path/to/input/**` and `/path/to/input/nested/dirs/actualfile.txt`). Full path or at least intermediate directories would help differentiate between files read from different directories with the same filenames. ResourceIds would also allow WholeFileIO to write out to nested directories that mirror the directory structures read from, and reduce the user effort necessary to avoid passing PCollection elements with the same filenames to WholeFileIO.Write, which will currently overwrite each other.
2. `KV<String/ResourceId, byte[]>` works for my use case, but it might make it easier for others if WholeFileIO reads into and writes from some more abstracted `FileWrapper` object. With a `FileWrapper` object, I'm still open to handling an `InputStream` or something rather than `byte[]` as Robert Bradshaw mentioned may be possible in the mailing list conversation, but I don't know how that would work. I imagine `InputStream`s don't serialize well in `Coder`s.
R: @vikkyrk

Ok, I've just applied suggested changes. Can you please take a look?
Some findbugs errors are remaining.

Hi @jkff, thanks for your comments: 
Here is the link for the discussion on the ML: https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/95a0564b3c2a8a6882b9870bcf24ed6c9d27157741be94780588c9e0@%3Cdev.beam.apache.org%3E

Main difference for us (in addition to new ES features not yet implemented in the IO) is that ES5 allows to do a real split whereas with ES2 shards could not been split leading to ignoring desiredBundleSize. I would have preferred a single module as I wrote on the ML: in a first implementation before the decision on the ML I thought about having a single maven module and detecting the ES backend version and then basically use` if (version)` where needed.  But there are several points that led to 2 modules:
1. UTests need a real instance (e.g. to properly test split) that is why they use embedded ES, and we cannot have both versions in the same artifact. 
2. For ES5 we have to use the test framework that leads to some differences in the tests. 
3. split tests are very different as explained above
4. dependencies of the 2 modules are very different

From the user point of view: the same pipeline will run against ES2 and ES5 modulo the change of the io dependency in user pom

Thanks for the pointer on the PTransform guide. I have already seen the `DataStoreIO` but it would break backward compatibility of user pipelines to use `DataStoreV1` class where they previously had `DataStoreIO` class. Besides having `DataStoreV1`  and a future `DataStoreV2` classes implementing the whole IO (as it is actually done in `DataStoreV1`) would lead to a lot of code duplication. That is why I preferred factorizing 90% of the code in ElasticsearchIOCore and only use 4 specialization points (see ElasticsearchRequester interface). If you have a better design that allows no code duplication and a total pipeline code backward compatibility, I'm all ears :)
retest this please
trying to merge...
merged, please close it when you've time.

It's getting difficult to follow all the comment threads. Please post an explicit update on this PR when you'd like me to take another look. I also stand by my suggestion to start with adding just one of these transforms - for the additional reason that it'll make it easier to deal with Github's shall we say questionable code review UI.

Thanks for the explanations. It's unfortunate that there hasn't been much of a discussion on the mailing list - my apologies, I didn't pay attention to the original thread because I didn't realize that this is a hard problem and what would be the consequences of not paying attention to it :)

Sounds like the main differences are in testing. Even the pom.xml's for ES2 and ES5 differ only in test-scope dependencies. I believe this means that non-test usage and implementation of ES2 and ES5 can remain the same.

How about we have only 1 module implementing ElasticsearchIO using `if(version)` (detecting the version transparently to the user), but have 2 modules `beam-sdks-java-io-elasticsearch-tests-{2,5}` testing it respectively against ES2 and ES5? Then all the versioning and dependency weirdness stuff will be isolated to these test-only modules invisibly to users of ElasticsearchIO.
retest this please.
Seems like this only failed in Python tests which are unaffected by your change. You can merge this.

retest this please

+1, as I wrote in the ML and in this PR, I prefer having only one module. I very much like your suggestion of having only `beam-sdks-java-io-elasticsearch-tests-{2,5}`. Thanks! Having only one production module will solve almost all the problems : no more module complexity for the user, no more too wide visibility for core classes, no more (static) requester.

I only have one concern left: point 3 in PR initial comment : the jarHell hack I did (please see javadoc comment as well), that obviously should not be there. Do you know how to configure surefire plugin to exclude the duplicate class from classpath?
```
java.lang.RuntimeException: found jar hell in test classpath
	at org.elasticsearch.bootstrap.BootstrapForTesting.<clinit>(BootstrapForTesting.java:90)
	at org.elasticsearch.test.ESTestCase.<clinit>(ESTestCase.java:138)
	at java.lang.Class.forName0(Native Method)
	at java.lang.Class.forName(Class.java:348)
	at com.carrotsearch.randomizedtesting.RandomizedRunner$2.run(RandomizedRunner.java:592)
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: jar hell!
class: org.apache.maven.surefire.report.SafeThrowable
jar1: /home/echauchot/.m2/repository/org/apache/maven/surefire/surefire-api/2.20/surefire-api-2.20.jar
jar2: /home/echauchot/.m2/repository/org/apache/maven/surefire/surefire-junit47/2.20/surefire-junit47-2.20.jar
	at org.elasticsearch.bootstrap.JarHell.checkClass(JarHell.java:291)
	at org.elasticsearch.bootstrap.JarHell.checkJarHell(JarHell.java:187)
	at org.elasticsearch.bootstrap.JarHell.checkJarHell(JarHell.java:88)
	at org.elasticsearch.bootstrap.BootstrapForTesting.<clinit>(BootstrapForTesting.java:88)
```
- `classpathDependencyExcludes` only excludes artifacts
- I can not use an isolated classloader (http://maven.apache.org/surefire/maven-surefire-plugin/examples/class-loading.html) because the original JarHell class calls `System.getProperty("java.class.path")` that will not contain ES jars in the case of isolated classloader
- As I need a real ES instance running (I really want strong UTests not mocked ones), I could avoid the ES test framework by forking an ES process to run UTests against it, but it might be a bit complicated.

WDYT?

I chose to flatten all the modules to make it simple but if you want I can create an `elasticsearch-parent` module to factorize tests dependencies of the `elasticsearch-tests-x` modules

Note that after this change, it makes less sense to use the DirectRunner without .wait_until_finish(), as termination of the main thread will implicitly terminate any running pipelines.

> as termination of the main thread will implicitly terminate any running pipelines.

This is different compared to cluster based runners, however I think it makes sense. Do you think we should have a log message if we can detect a pre-mature termination with `DirectRunner`?
